awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Sharad Mehrotra and an interdisciplinary team of collaborators at the University of California at Irvine (UCI) will develop I-sensorium, to serve as a "living laboratory" to support research in several related areas of cyber-physical systems: including theoretical foundations and underlying principles of building sentient systems; engineering, software, and systems level challenges; and novel application contexts where such sentient systems can be used. I-Sensorium will serve as a testbed for exploring and testing novel sentient technologies. I-Sensorium augments Responsphere, an existing UCI crisis response test-bed with state-of-the-art storage and computational infrastructure to acquire and process continuous streams of sensory data from Responsphere sensors. The I-Sensorium software will leverage multiple ongoing research projects at UCI on large-scale, heterogeneous sensor databases, sensor middleware platforms for querying and analysis of heterogeneous sensor data, and an event representation system for multi-media data, to provide  a high level programming environment for the I-Sensorium allowing a broad group of researchers to participate and benefit from its creation. 

The development of I-Sensorium offers opportunities for research-based education and training in many aspects of cyber-physical systems. The infrastructure as well as  the sensor data acquisition enabled by it presents research challenges and opportunities in  sensor data management, machine learning, computer vision, event modeling, among others. Interactions with industrial partners and government agencies are expected to lead to advances in the applications of cyber-physical systems in real-world settings. Education and outreach efforts  are aimed at broadening the participation of women and members of underrepresented groups in computer science and engineering. Further information about this project can be found at: http://www.i-sensorium.org

por.por_cntn:
The I-sensorium was an infrastructure creation project to support research on interactive sentient systems -- i.e., environments where sensors monitor the physical space and the awareness gained is used to adapt the environment. The infrastructure was built to support research spanning theoretical foundations, underlying principles, engineering, software design, systems level challenges, as well as novel application contexts for sentient spaces.

The project instrumented Bren Hall (which houses the school of Computer Science) with diverse sensors (e.g., PTZ cameras, Raspberry Pis, beacons, mobile sensing devices, in-house assembled sensor platforms with heterogeneous communication capabilities, RFID sensors, array of motes with diverse sensing capabilities, temperature sensors, mobile cameras, gas sensors, vibration sensors, motion sensors, occupancy sensors, and people counters), thus creating  a smart building that could monitor its day-to-day usage. In addition, several server machines (including a cluster of 38 nodes) and a storage server with over 60TB of storage was purchased to process and store the continuous streams of data generated by I-sensorium sensors.

From a software perspective, I-Sensorium includes two major software artifacts, both of which are large independent research project funded through other means: First, a system entitled SATWARE was developed to support adaptive data collection from heterogeneous sensors and to process raw sensor data to generate semantically meaningful events. Second, a new database technology, AsterixDB, was developed; it supports semi-structured data, partitioned parallelism, and a SQL-style query language to enable scalable query processing over massive sensory datasets such as those generated by I-sensorium sensors.

Throughout its development, I-sensorium has supported ongoing research at UCI in a variety of ways: as a research testbed – viz., a “living laboratory” to explore variety of challenges in building sentient spaces (e.g., robustness, resilience, etc); as a generator of live rich granular sensor data feeds to explore variety of event detection, data mining, and data management tasks; and as a platform to build novel sensor­-based applications. Research supported by I­-Sensorium can be roughly classified into three major areas: (a) Scalable Observation System challenges – a collection of projects focusing on overcoming the heterogeneity and scale of sensor data that is expected to be generated in sentient environments, (b)  Awareness challenges – a set of projects exploring approaches to bridge the “semantic gap” between observations from sensors and the awareness needed to build sentient applications, and  (c)  Adaptation challenges - a set of projects exploring specific sentient space applications and their adaptation requirements.

The infrastructure has benefited a multitude of projects related to high performance computing, secure cloud computing, pervasive computing, multimedia processing, vision processing, reliable cyber physical spaces, sensor data mining, and data cleaning. It has supported research projects of the PIs (Mehrotra, Carey, Jain, Venkatasubramanian) as well as many additional faculty at UCI (e.g., Fawlkes, Tsudik, Dutt, Ihler, Ramanan, Harris,  Xu). It has also been used by researchers at remote locations including Technion, UT Dallas, CMU, U-Massachusetts, Duke, Colgate, and Zhejiang University. Over the years, the infrastructure has played a vital role in the dissertation topics of about 20 Ph.D. students and it continues to be a vital infrastructure for at least 20 additional students.
